Q: Find all eigenvalues and eigenvector for each eigenvalue.
$$A = \matrixstart 0 & 5 & 3 \\ 1 & 1 & 0 \\ -3 & 6 & 5 \matrixend$$

A: First, we compute
$p(\lambda) = \det(A - \lambda I) = (-\lambda)\left[ (1-\lambda)(5-\lambda) \right] - 5 \left[ 5-\lambda \right] + 3 \left[ 6 + 3(1-\lambda) \right] \\
= (\lambda^2 - \lambda)(5-\lambda) + 5\lambda - 25 + 27 - 9\lambda \\
= -\lambda^3 + 6\lambda^2 -5\lambda -4\lambda + 2 \\
= -\lambda^3 + 6\lambda^2 -9\lambda + 2 = 0$

We can see that $\lambda_1 = 2$ is a solution, so we get
$(\lambda - 2)(-\lambda^2 + 4\lambda - 1) = (\lambda + 2)(\lambda^2 - 4\lambda + 1) = 0$

In the case where $\lambda^2 - 4\lambda + 1 = 0$, we have
$\lambda^2 - 4\lambda + 1 = (\lambda - 2)^2 - 3$
$(\lambda - 2)^2 = 3$
$\lambda_{2,3} = 2 \pm \sqrt{3}$

Eigenvectors:

For $\lambda_1 = 2$, we have $A - \lambda I = \matrixstart -2 & 5 & 3 \\ 1 & -1 & 0 \\ -3 & 6 & 3 \matrixend$

This is row-equivalent to $\matrixstart 0 & 1 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \matrixend$
So $v_1 = \matrixstart -1 \\ -1 \\ 1 \matrixend$

For $\lambda_2 = 2 + \sqrt{3}$, we have $A - \lambda I = \matrixstart -2 - \sqrt{3} & 5 & 3 \\ 1 & -1 - \sqrt{3} & 0 \\ -3 & 6 & 3 - \sqrt{3} \matrixend$

This is row-equivalent to $\matrixstart 0 & 3 & -\sqrt{3} \\ 1 & 0 & \frac{-3-\sqrt{3}}{3} \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \matrixend$
So $v_2 = \matrixstart \frac{3+\sqrt{3}}{3} \\ \frac{\sqrt{3}}{3} \\ 1 \matrixend$

For $\lambda_3 = 2 - \sqrt{3}$, we simply negate the roots in $v_2$

So $v_3 = \matrixstart \frac{3-\sqrt{3}}{3} \\ \frac{-\sqrt{3}}{3} \\ 1 \matrixend$
